abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, in addition to
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            Notwithstanding success, a number of lessons are suggested.
            First, reforms involving the realignment of public
            expenditures, as well as increasing the transparency, and
            broadening of participation in government decision-making
            and implementation, require profound changes in ingrained
            social attitudes, which threaten, or are perceived to
            threaten, entrenched interests. Nevertheless, the project
            proved itself a very effective instrument for maintaining a
            constructive dialogue, and pressure to move forward on a
            coherent and focused policy agenda. Moreover, by bringing
            the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) into a central
            role in the negotiation of the social agenda, and
            responsibility for its implementation, the Program also
            effectively engaged the influence, and commitment of the
            state budget to push the reforms forward, and to provide the
            necessary resources. Social reforms are inevitably
            experimental, and strong monitoring and evaluation (M&E)
            systems are essential in drawing the lessons of pilot
            efforts, to refining instruments, and in guiding the
            adjustment of policies and programs over time. While M&E
            development was supported from the beginning of the program,
            many delays in design and implementation of monitoring
            tools, limited the possibility to assess the evolution of
            programs. Finally, in the face of strong political pressures
            to transfer resources to regional government programs and to
            raise salaries, the inclusion of the Program conditionality
            may have succeeded in preventing some erosion of the funding
            available for the selected programs, as well as in
            encouraging their closer monitoring and evaluation.
